title: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS)
icd10: G56.40 (Causalgia of unspecified upper limb — CRPS II)
G57.70 (Causalgia of unspecified lower limb — CRPS II)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS) Types I and II in adults. Includes Budapest diagnostic criteria, staging, etiologic workup, pharmacologic management (neuropathic pain agents, bisphosphonates, corticosteroids), interventional procedures (sympathetic blocks, spinal cord stimulation), and rehabilitation (graded motor imagery, mirror therapy). Covers ED acute pain management, inpatient evaluation, outpatient chronic management, and ICU-level ketamine infusion protocols. Excludes other chronic pain syndromes unless part of differential.

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Educate on CRPS as a real, treatable neurological condition
Patient/Family Instructions.rationale: Combat stigma; improve treatment engagement; reduce catastrophizing

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Active use of affected limb encouraged within pain tolerance
Patient/Family Instructions.rationale: Disuse leads to worsening dystrophy, contracture, and central sensitization

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Home mirror therapy and GMI exercises daily
Patient/Family Instructions.rationale: Cortical reorganization requires consistent daily practice for efficacy

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Avoid immobilization of affected limb (no slings, casts unless fracture)
Patient/Family Instructions.rationale: Immobilization worsens CRPS; evidence for harm from prolonged rest

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Apply warm or cool packs per patient preference to affected area
Patient/Family Instructions.rationale: Symptom relief; patient-directed (some prefer warmth, others cold)

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Report new weakness, spreading pain to other limbs, color changes, skin breakdown, or worsening pain promptly
Patient/Family Instructions.rationale: Early detection of disease progression, spread, or complications

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Avoid surgical procedures on the affected limb unless absolutely necessary
Patient/Family Instructions.rationale: Surgery on CRPS-affected limb can cause flare or spread; preoperative sympathetic block recommended if surgery unavoidable

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Keep a pain diary tracking daily pain levels, triggers, sleep, and functional activities
Patient/Family Instructions.rationale: Facilitates treatment titration and objective progress monitoring at follow-up visits

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Vitamin C 500 mg daily after fracture or surgery
Lifestyle & Prevention.rationale: Evidence supports prophylactic vitamin C (500 mg/day x 50 days) to reduce CRPS incidence after wrist fracture

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Early mobilization after fracture or surgery
Lifestyle & Prevention.rationale: Prolonged immobilization is a known risk factor for CRPS development

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Stress management and relaxation techniques (mindfulness, paced breathing, progressive muscle relaxation)
Lifestyle & Prevention.rationale: Psychological stress exacerbates CRPS symptoms and central sensitization
Poor sleep amplifies central sensitization and pain perception
Smoking impairs microvascular flow and wound healing; worsens CRPS outcomes

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular low-impact aerobic exercise (walking, cycling, swimming)
Lifestyle & Prevention.rationale: General conditioning, mood improvement, pain modulation via endorphin release
Reduce repetitive strain on affected limb; activity modification to promote function without overload

differential.features: Claudication; diminished pulses; ABI <0.9; trophic changes in vascular distribution; no allodynia

differential.features: Pain localized to tendon; worsened by specific motion; no vasomotor, sudomotor, or trophic changes

differential.features: Episodic burning pain, erythema, warmth in distal extremities; bilateral; relieved by cooling; no edema or trophic changes
differential.tests: History of episodic symptoms; relief with cooling; genetic testing (SCN9A); no bone scan changes
